description: TO AMEND S. 3065. THE MODIFIED MATHIAS AMENDMENT ADDS TWO MEMBERS TO THE FEDERAL  ELECTION COMMISSION WHO ARE NOT AFFILIATED WITH ANY POLITICAL PARTY.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AMEND S. 3065, BY MAKING PERMISSABLE CONTRIBUTIONS BY AN INDIVIDUAL FROM $1000 TO  $5000 AND RAISING PERMISSABLE CONTRIBUTIONS BY A POLITICAL COMMITTEE FOR A SINGLE PRESIDENTIAL OR SENATORIAL CANDIDATE FROM $5000 TO $25,000 AND $10,000 TO A CANDIDATE FOR THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTIVES.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO TABLE THE CHILES  AMENDMENT TO THE GRIFFIN SUBSTITUTE TO S. 3065.  THE CHILES AMENDMENT  PROHIBITS ARTIFICAL LEGAL ENTITIES FROM CONTRIBUTING TO FEDERAL ELECTION CAMPAIGNS, AND ALLOWS INDIVIDUALS ONLY TO MAKE CONTRIBUTIONS TO A CANDIDATE'S CAMPAIGN.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AMEND THE GRIFFIN AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO S. 3065.  (SEE RC 80).
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO TABLE A MOTION  TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE BY WHICH CHILES AMENDMENT TO S. 3065 WAS   REJECTED.  (SEE RC 80
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE BY WHICH THE CHILES AMENDMENT TO S. 3065 WAS REJECTED.  (SEE RC 80)
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AMEND S. 3065 IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE, AS AMENDED. THE GRIFFIN SUBSTITUTE  PROVIDES FOR THE SIMPLE RECONSTITUTION OF THE FEC WITH 6 PRESIDENTIALLY APPOINTED MEMBERS AND REQUIRES LABOR UNIONS AND CORPORATIONS TO DISCLOSE EXPENDITURES ON INTERNAL POLITICAL ACTIVITY.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AMEND S. 3065, SO AS TO INCREASE   FROM $5000 TO $20,000 THE MAXIMUM CONTRIBUTION  WHICH MAY BE MADE TO A CANDIDATE BY THE DEMOCRATIC OR REPUBLICAN SENATORIAL AND CONGRESSIONAL COMMITTEES OR BY THE NATIONAL COMMITTEE OF ANY PARTY WITH RESPECT TO ANY OR ALL ELECTIONS.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO PASS S. 641, THE CONSUMER FOOD ACT, REQUIRING SURVEILLANCE REGULATIONS FOR THE  DETECTION AND PREVENTIONS OF ADULTERATED FOOD.

TO AMEND S. RES. 406 RELATING TO THE IMPORTANCE OF SOUND RELATIONS WITH THE SOVIET  UNION.  THE ALLEN AMENDMENT PROVIDES THAT THE RESOLUTION NOT BECOME EFFECTIVE UNTIL THE SENATE PASSES A SUBSEQUENT RESOLUTION DECLARING THAT THE U.S.S.R. HAS TAKEN ACTION TO DO SUCH THINGS AS THE RESOLUTION SUGGESTS BE DONE AFTER AN AGREEMENT IS SIGNED.

TO REFER S. RES. 406, STATING THE SENSE OF THE SENATE WITH RESPECT TO THE IMPORTANCE  OF SOUND U.S. RELATIONS WITH THE U.S.S.R., AND THE PENDING ALLEN AMENDMENT TO THE COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN RELATIONS.  (SEE RC 87)

TO AMEND H.R. 12203 MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR FOREIGN ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS FOR FISCAL  YEAR 1976 AND THROUGH SEPTEMBER 30, 1976.  THE BYRD AMENDMENT REDUCES FROM $189.5 MILLION TO $125 MILLION FUNDING FOR INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS AND PROGRAMS.
TO PASS H.R. 12203.  (SEE RC 89)
TO AMEND S. 3065 BY REQUIRING ANY GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEE EARNING IN EXCESS OF  $25,000 ANNUAL SALARY TO FILE ANNUALLY A FINANCIAL STATEMENT WITH THE COMPTROLLER GENERAL.
TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 9803 TO PROVIDE CHILD DAY CARE  SERVICES UNDER TITLE XX OF THE SOCIAL SECURITY ACT.
TO TABLE DIVISION 1 OF THE ALLEN AMENDMENT TO S. 3065. DIVISION 1 OF THE ALLEN  AMENDMENT LIMITS THE AMOUNT OF HONORARIA WHICH MAY BE ACCEPTED BY GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS TO $15,000 PER ANNUM.

TO TABLE THE CRANSTON AMENDMENT TO S. 3065.  THE CRANSTON AMENDMENT PROVIDES  THAT A CORPORATION OR LABOR ORGANIZATION NEED NOT REPORT CONTRIBUTIONS UP TO $1,000 ON SEPERATE DAYS OR PER COMMUNICATION ON NON-PARTISAN POLITICAL ACTIVITIES.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AMEND THE CRANSTON AMENDMENT, (SEE RC 94 ), TO S. 3065. THE BUMPERS  AMENDMENT PROVIDES THAT A CORPORATION OR LABOR ORGANIZATION NEED NOT REPORT CONTRIBUTIONS UP TO $1000 PER CANDIDATE, PER ELECTION.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO PASS S. 3065, AS AMENDED.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO AMEND S. 3015, TO PROVIDE FOR THE CONTINUED EXPANSION AND IMPROVEMENT  OF THE NATION'S AIRPORT AND AIRWAY SYSTEM, TO STREAMLINE THE GRANT-IN-AID PROCESS AND STRENGTHEN NATIONAL AIRPORT SYSTEM PLANNING.  THE WEICKER AMENDMENT PROHIBITS THE USE OF FEDERAL FUNDS FOR THE OPERATION OF CIVIL SUPERSONIC AIRCRAFT IN THE UNITED STATES.
TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO THE BEALL AMENDMENT TO S. 3015 (SEE RC 99).  THE BUMPER'S AMENDMENT REQUIRES THAT CIVIL SUPERSONIC AIRCRAFT MEET FAA NOISE STANDARDS.
TO AMEND S. 3015 BY REQUIRING CIVIL TRANSPORT AIRCRAFT TO COMPLY WITH NOISE  LEVEL REQUIREMENTS FOR SUBSONIC TRANSPORT AIRCRAFT.
TO AMEND S. 3015, SO AS TO AUTHORIZE UTILIZATION OF SURPLUS AIRPORT AND AIRWAY  TRUST FUND MONIES TO MAINTAIN AIR SAFETY EQUIPMENT.
TO PASS S. 3015.

TO AMEND S. 3149 REGULATING COMMERCE AND PROTECTING HUMAN HEALTH AND THE  ENVIRONMENT BY REQUIRING TESTING AND THE NECESSARY USE RESTRICTIONS ON CERTAIN TOXIC CHEMICAL SUBSTANCES.  THE HELMS AMENDMENT DELETES THE "EMPLOYMENT PROTECTION"  PROVISION OF THE ACT.
TO PASS S. 3149.  (SEE RC 102)

TO TABLE THE SPARKMAN AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO THE BARTLETT  AMENDMENT TO S. 3168, AUTHORIZING FUNDS FOR FISCAL YEAR 1977 FOR THE DEPARTMENT OF STATE, THE USIA, AND THE BOARD FOR INTERNATIONAL BROADCASTING.  THE MODIFIED SPARKMAN AMENDMENT CALLS FOR THE U.S. AMBASSADOR TO THE U.N. TO SEEK CHANGES IN THE U.N. SYSTEM FOR APPORTIONING RATES OF ASSESSMENT BY HAVING NATIONS ASSESSED ACCORDING TO THEIR ABILITY TO PAY WHILE THE BARTLETT AMENDMENT SPECIFIED A REDUCTION OF 10% OVER A PERIOD OF FIVE YEARS IN U.S. CONTRIBUTION TO THE U.N. BUDGET.
TO PASS S. 3168.  (SEE RC 104)

TO AMEND S. 354, A BILL REQUIRING NO-FAULT MOTOR INSURANCE. THE FORD AMENDMENT  LIMITS THE LEGAL OBLIGATION OF AN INSURANCE COMPANY PROVIDING NO-FAULT BENEFITS TO A MAXIMUM OF $250,000, THEREBY ASSURING THAT ALL INSURANCE COMPANIES CAN COMPETE ON AN EQUITABLE BASIS, REGARDLESS OF COMPANY SIZE.
TO RECOMMIT TO THE COMMITTEE ON COMMERCE S. 354.
TO TABLE THE MOTION TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE BY WHICH THE MOTION TO RECOMMIT  S. 354, WAS AGREED TO.
TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON THE DISAGREEING VOTES OF THE TWO HOUSES  ON THE AMENDMENTS OF THE SENATE TO H.R. 8617, THE FEDERAL EMPLOYEES ACTIVITIES ACT OF 1975.

TO TABLE THE SCOTT (VA.) AMENDMENT TO S. 287, A BILL TO CREATE ADDITIONAL  JUDGESHIPS IN SELECTED JUDICIAL DISTRICTS IN THE U.S. THE SCOTT AMENDMENT PROVIDES THAT NO FEDERAL COURT HAS ANY JURISDICTION TO HEAR OR DECIDE CASES OR CONTROVERSIES INVOLVING PUBLIC SCHOOLS.

TO TABLE THE ROTH AMENDMENT TO S. 287. THE ROTH AMENDMENT PROVIDES THAT NO  FEDERAL COURT SHALL HAVE JURISDICTION TO ENTER A DECREE REQUIRING THE  TRANPORTATION OF STUDENTS OR TEACHERS IN ORDER TO CARRY OUT RACIAL DESEGREGATION OF ANY SCHOOL OR SCHOOL SYSTEM.
TO TABLE THE TOWER AMENDMENT TO S. 287.  THE TOWER AMENDMENT PROVIDES ONE  ADDITIONAL DISTRICT JUDGE FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS.
TO PASS S. 287.

TO TABLE THE CURTIS AMENDMENT TO S. 3136, THE NATIONAL FOOD STAMP REFORM ACT OF  1976.  THE CURTIS AMENDMENT PROVIDES THAT REFUSAL TO WORK AT A PLANT BECAUSE OF A STRIKE SHALL BE DEEMED A REFUSAL TO ACCEPT EMPLOYMENT, EXCEPT THAT NO HOUSEHOLD SHALL BE INELIGIBLE FOR FOOD STAMPS BECAUSE OF THE STRIKE STATUS OF ONE OF ITS MEMBERS IF IT WERE ELIGIBLE PRIOR TO THE STRIKE.
TO AMEND S. 3136, BY INCORPORATING INTO LAW DOLLAR LIMITS ON ASSETS OF  RECIPIENTS  OF FOOD STAMPS.
TO AMEND S. 3136, BY INCREASING FROM 30 TO 90 DAYS THE PERIOD PRIOR TO  APPLICATION IN DETERMING INCOME OF HOUSEHOLDS.

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT TO THE HOUSE AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE  TO S. CON. RES. 98, TO PROVIDE FOR A DELEGATION TO GO TO THE UNITED KINGDOM TO ACCEPT A LOAN OF AN ORIGINAL COPY OF THE MAGNA CARTA.  THE BARTLETT AMENDMENT REDUCES THE CONGRESSIONAL DELEGATION FROM 24 TO 8.
TO TABLE THE MOTION TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE BY WHICH BARTLETT'S AMENDMENT TO  S. CON. RES. 98 WAS AGREED TO. (SEE RC 117).
TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE BY WHICH THE BARTLETT AMENDMENT TO S. CON RES. 98 WAS AGREED TO.  (SEE RC 117 AND 118)

TO TABLE S. RES. 268, TO AMEND SENATE RULE 22 SO AS TO PROVIDE THAT, EXCEPT  BY UNANIMOUS CONSENT, NO AMENDMENT SHALL BE PROPOSED AFTER THE VOTE TO BRING DEBATE TO A CLOSE UNLESS THE SAME HAS BEEN SUBMITTED IN WRITING TO THE JOURNAL CLERK PRIOR TO THE END OF THE VOTE.

TO AMEND S. RES. 268.  THE KENNEDY AMENDMENT, AS MODIFIED, TO THE COMMITTEE  AMENDMENT SUPPLIES SUBSTITUTE LANGUAGE "UNLESS THE SAME HAS BEEN SUBMITTED TO THE CLERK PRIOR TO THE END OF THE CLOTURE VOTE.
TO AMEND THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT TO S. RES. 268.  THE ALLEN AMENDMENT PROVIDES  THAT NO AMENDMENT SHALL BE PROPOSED AFTER THE CLOTURE VOTE INSTEAD OF NO AMENDMENT SHALL BE IN ORDER AFTER THE VOTE.
TO AMEND S. 3136, BY DISALLOWING FOOD STAMPS FOR STUDENTS.
TO AMEND S. 3136, BY REQUIRING STUDENTS TO MEET WORK REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS  IN ORDER TO RECEIVE FOOD STAMPS.
TO AMEND S. 3136, BY ALLOWING AN ADDITIONAL $25 PER MONTH DEDUCTION FOR ANY  HOUSEHOLD CONTAINING AT LEAST ONE INDIVIDUAL AGE 65 OR OVER RATHER THAN 60 OR OVER.
TO AMEND S. 3136, BY REDUCING FROM 12 TO 6 YEARS THE AGE OF DEPENDENT CHILDREN  FOR PURPOSES OF WORK REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS OF THE BILL.
TO AMEND S. 3136, BY REDUCING THE STANDARD DEDUCTION FROM $100 TO $50 PER  HOUSEHOLD PER MONTH.
TO AMEND S. 3136, BY DISALLOWING FOOD STAMPS FOR ANY FULL TIME FEDERAL, STATE,  OR LOCAL GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEE.
TO AMEND S. 3136, BY SETTING THE PURCHASE REQUIREMENTS TO 30% OF THE ADJUSTED  GROSS MONTHLY INCOME, RATHER THAN 27.5%.
TO AMEND S. 3136, BY PROVIDING THAT THE EXCEPTION IN THE BILL FOR FULL TIME  STUDENTS NOT APPLY IN THE CASE OF A STUDENT WHEN HE HAS A BREAK IN THE SCHOOL YEAR OR IS BETWEEN SEMESTERS.
TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON S. 1941, THE ANIMAL WELFARE ACT AMENDMENTS  OF 1976.
TO SUSPEND CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS OF THE CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET ACT SO AS TO ALLOW  CONSIDERATION OF S. 3136 AND ANY AMENDMENTS THERETO PRIOR TO PASSAGE OF THE FIRST CONCURRENT BUDGET RESOLUTION OF 1977.

TO TABLE THE DOLE-MCGOVERN SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT NO. 1571, AS AMENDED, IN THE  NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO S. 3136.  THE DOLE MCGOVERN SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT REDUCES THE PURCHASE REQUIREMENT FROM 27.5 PERCENT OF NET INCOME TO 25%, PROVIDES FOR SEMI-ANNUAL ADJUSTMENT OF THE STANDARD DEDUCTION AND THE OFFICIAL GOVERNMENT POVERTY INDEX, PROVIDES AN  ADDITIONAL $25 PER MONTH DEDUCTION FOR WORKING HOUSEHOLDS, AND MANDATES A PILOT PROGRAM ON ELIMINATION OF THE PURCHASE REQUIREMENT.
TO TABLE THE ALLEN AMENDMENT NO. 1550 THE DOLE MCGOVERN AMENDMENT TO S. 3136.  THE ALLEN AMENDMENT ELIMINATES THE FOOD STAMP PURCHASE REQUIREMENTS.

TO TABLE THE ALLEN AMENDMENT TO THE DOLE-MCGOVERN AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A  SUBSTITUTE TO S. 3136.  THE ALLEN AMENDMENT STRIKES SECTION 21 OF THE DOLE-MCGOVERN AMENDMENT WHICH PROVIDES $20 MILLION FOR SETTING UP A PILOT PROGRAM TO TRY OUT THE SYSTEM OF REQUIRING NO PURCHASE PRICE FOR FOOD STAMPS.

TO TABLE THE ALLEN AMENDMENT TO THE DOLE-MCGOVERN AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A  SUBSTITUTE TO S 3136.  THE ALLEN AMENDMENT INCREASES THE PURCHASE PRICE OF STAMPS FROM 25% TO 27.5% OF THE FAMILY NET INCOME.
TO AGREE TO AMENDMENT NO. 1571 IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO S. 3136.
TO PASS S. 3136, AS AMENDED BY THE DOLE-MCGOVERN AMENDMENT NO. 9571.
TO PASS S. 2853, AS AMENDED, TO AMEND THE FOOD STAMP ACT OF 1964 BY INSURING A  PROPER LEVEL OF ACCOUNTABILITY ON THE PART OF FOOD STAMP VENDORS.

TO TABLE THE CRANSTON AMENDMENT TO S. CON. RES. 109, SETTING FORTH THE  CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET FOR THE FISCAL YEAR 1977. THE CRANSTON AMENDMENT INCREASES BY $800 MILLION BUDGET AUTHORITY AND OUT LAYS FOR VETERANS' ADMINISTRATION PROGRAMS.

TO TABLE THE LONG AMENDMENT TO S. CON. RES. 109.  THE LONG AMENDMENT CUTS $2  BILLION IN COUNTER CYCLICAL REVENUE SHARING AND EXTENDED UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION, AND TRANSFERS SUCH AMOUNT TO COVER ADDITIONAL COSTS IN MEDICARE AND MEDICAID AND OTHER INCOME SECURITY AREAS.
TO PASS H.J. RES. 890 MAKING EMERGENCY SUPPLEMENTAL APPROPRIATIONS FOR PUBLIC  EMPLOYMENT PROGRAMS, SUMMER YOUTH PROGRAMS AND PREVENTATIVE HEALTH SERVICES FOR THE FISCAL YEAR ENDING JUNE 30, 1976.
TO AMEND S. CON. RES. 109, BY INCREASING BY $100 MILLION THE FUND FOR LAW  ENFORCEMENT FUNCTIONS.
TO AMEND S. CON. RES. 109, IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE BILL, BY PROPOSING  CUTS OF $4.5 BILLION IN BUDGET AUTHORITY AND $6.8 BILLION IN OUTLAYS.
TO AMEND S. CON. RES. 109, BY PROPOSING CUTS OF $2.6 BILLION IN BUDGET  AND $500 MILLION IN NATIONAL DEFENSE OUTLAYS.
TO AMEND S. CON. RES. 109 BY INCREASING FUNDS FOR AGRICULTURE BY $100  MILLION IN BUDGET AUTHORITY AND $150 MILLION IN OUTLAYS.
TO AGREE TO S. CON. RES. 109, BY INCREASING BY $3.2 BILLION OUTLAYS FOR JOBS, HEALTH, AGING PROGRAMS, AND URBAN AND RURAL DEVELOPMENT.
TO PASS S. CON. RES. 109.

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT, AS MODIFIED, TO S. 3201, THE PUBLIC WORKS EMPLOYMENT  ACT OF 1976.  THE AMENDMENT INCLUDES PROVISIONS FOR A COUNTERCYCLICAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM WHICH AUTHORIZES $1.38 BILLION TO STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS AND $1.42 BILLION FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF WASTE WATER TREATMENT FACILITIES.
TO PASS S. 3201, AS AMENDED, AUTHORIZING FUNDS FOR ANTI-RECESSIONARY PUBLIC  WORKS EMPLOYMENT PROGRAMS.  (SEE RC 149).
TO AMEND S. 3055, TO PROVIDE FOR U.S. STANDARDS AND A NATIONAL INSPECTION  SYSTEM FOR GRAIN, BY DELETING A PROVISION REQUIRING FEDERAL INSPECTION AT INLAND TERMINALS.
TO AMEND S. 3055, (SEE R C 151) BY DELETING PROVISIONS ESTABLISHING A SEPARATE  FEDERAL GRAIN INSPECTION AGENCY.

TO PASS H.R. 12572, AS AMENDED, TO AMEND THE UNITED STATES GRAIN STANDARDS ACT  TO IMPROVE THE GRAIN INSPECTION AND WEIGHING SYSTEM, AFTER STRIKING ALL AFTER THE ENACTING CLAUSE AND INSERTING PROVISIONS OF THE SENATE COMPANION BILL, S. 3055.
TO RECOMMIT TO THE COMMITTEE ON BANKING, HOUSING, AND URBAN AFFAIRS S. 3259,  EXTENDING CERTAIN HOUSING PROGRAMS UNDER THE NATIONAL HOUSING ACT.
TO PASS S. 3259, EXTENDING CERTAIN HOUSING PROGRAMS UNDER THE NATIONAL  HOUSING ACT.
TO TABLE THE MOTION TO PROCEED TO THE CONSIDERATION S. J. RES. 178, PROPOSING  AN AMENDMENT TO THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES GUARANTEEING THE RIGHT OF LIFE TO THE UNBORN.
TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON S. 2662, TO AMEND THE FOREIGN ASSISTANCE  ACT OF 1961 AND THE FOREIGN MILITARY SALES ACT SO AS TO PROVIDE MORE CONGRESSIONAL CONTROL OF U.S. ARMS SALES.
TO AGREE TO S. RES. 104, AS AMENDED, GRANTING LEGISLATIVE JURISDICTION TO THE  SELECT COMMITTEE ON SMALL BUSINESS ON ALL PROPOSED LEGISLATION RELATING TO THE SMALL BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION.
TO PASS S. 1737, TO AMEND THE PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE ACT TO ENCOURAGE THE  ESTABLISHMENT OF UNIFORM STANDARDS FOR LICENSING AND REGULATION OF CLINICAL LABORATORIES.

TO AMEND S. 2555, TO ESTABLISH A NATIONAL RANGELANDS REHABILITATION AND  PROTECTION PROGRAM, BY PROVIDING THAT RANGE GRAZING PERMITS BE FOR TEN-YEAR PERIODS, AND REQUIRING TWO-YEAR NOTICE PRIOR TO CANCELLATION.
TO AMEND THE MCCLURE AMENDMENT TO S. 2555, BY PROVIDING THAT RANGE PERMITS BE  FOR FIVE-YEAR PERIODS, AND REQUIRING A TWO-YEAR NOTICE BEFORE CANCELLATION. (SEE R.C. 162)

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT, AS AMENDED, TO S. 2555.  THE MCCLURE AMENDMENT  PERMITS PAYMENT OF UP TO 50% OF THE AMOUNT DUE THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT FROM GRAZING PERMITTEES IN THE FORM OF RANGE IMPROVEMENT WORK.

TO AGREE TO S. RES. 437, STATING THE SENSE OF THE SENATE THAT IT MAKE EVERY  EFFORT TO REACH, BY JULY 2, 1976, A VOTE ON THE QUESTION OF PASSAGE OF WATERGATE REFORM, TAX PRIVACY, AND INTELLIGENCE OVERSIGHT LEGISLATION.
TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON S. 3065, PROPOSED FEDERAL ELECTION  CAMPAIGN ACT AMENDMENTS OF 1976.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO OVERRIDE THE PRESIDENT'S VETO OF H.R. 9803, PROVIDING FOR A TEMPORARY  SUSPENSION OF CERTAIN FEDERAL CHILD DAY CARE STANDARDS.

TO AMEND S. RES. 406, RELATING TO THE IMPORTANCE OF SOUND RELATIONS WITH THE  SOVIET UNION, BY ADDING A SECTION WHICH PROVIDES THAT ANY FURTHER AGREEMENT SHOULD NOT LIMIT THE UNITED STATES TO LEVELS OF INTER-CONTINENTAL STRATEGIC FORCES INFERIOR TO THE LIMITS PROVIDED FOR THE SOVIET UNION.
TO AMEND S. RES. 406, BY CALLING FOR THE WITHDRAWAL OF CUBAN TROOPS FROM  AFRICA.
TO PASS S. RES. 406.
TO PASS S. 3103, AUTHORIZING $50 MILLION FOR INCREASES U.S. PARTICIPATION IN  THE ASIAN DEVELOPMENT FUND.
TO AMEND H.R. 13172, MAKING SUPPLEMENTAL APPROPRIATIONS FOR FISCAL YEAR 1976,  BY DELETING ALL FUNDING FOR THE NATIONAL COMMISSION ON THE OBSERVANCE OF INTERNATIONAL WOMEN'S YEAR, 1975.
TO AMEND H.R. 13172, BY INCREASING FROM $3 MILLION TO $5 MILLION FUNDING  FOR THE NATIONAL COMMISSION ON THE OBSERVANCE OF INTERNATIONAL WOMEN'S YEAR.
TO AMEND H.R. 13172, BY APPROPRIATING $1 BILLION TO CARRY OUT TITLE I OF THE  ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ACT.
TO PASS H.R. 13172.

TO AGREE TO THE HOUSE AMENDMENT WITH AN AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE  TO S. CON. RES. 109, SETTING FORTH RECOMMENDED LEVELS OF TOTAL BUDGET OUTLAYS, FEDERAL REVENUES, AND NEW BUDGET AUTHORITY.  THE HOUSE AMENDMENT IS ONLY IN MINOR TECHNICAL DISAGREEMENT.
TO AGREE TO THE CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 7656, TO ESTABLISH A PROGRAM  DESIGNED TO STRENGTHEN AND EXPAND THE MARKET FOR BEEF AND BEEF PRODUCTS.
TO AGREE TO THE CANNON AMENDMENT, AS MODIFIED, TO S. RES. 400, TO ESTABLISH A  SENATE COMMITTEE ON INTELLIGENCE ACTIVITIES.  THE AMENDMENT REDUCES FROM 17 TO 15 THE MEMBERSHIP OF SUCH A COMMITTEE.
TO TABLE THE ABOUREZK AMENDMENT TO S. RES. 400.  THE ABOUREZK AMENDMENT GIVES  THE COMMITTEE A GREATER DEGREE OF AUTHORITY TO DISCLOSE SENSITIVE INFORMATION.

TO AMEND THE CANNON AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE FOR S. RES. 400.  THE TAFT AMENDMENT WOULD ALLOW A SENATOR TO SERVE ON THE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE IN ADDITON TO ANY OTHER "MINOR" COMMITTEE ON WHICH HE PRESENTLY SERVES UNTIL THE 96TH CONGRESS.
TO AMEND THE CANNON AMENDMENT TO S. RES. 400 BY DENYING THE COMMITTEE ANY  JURISDICTION OVER THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE.
TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE TO S. RES. 400.
TO AGREE TO S. RES. 400, AS AMENDED.

TO AMEND S. 3434, THE MILITARY CONSTRUCTION AUTHORIZATION ACT OF 1977, BY  WAIVING THE PROVISIONS OF THE DAVIS-BACON ACT ON U.S. MILITARY CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS.  THE DAVIS-BACON ACT REQUIRES PAYMENT OF PREVAILING WAGES AND FRINGE BENEFITS TO WORKERS ON FEDERAL GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF PUBLIC BUILDINGS OR PUBLIC WORKS.

TO PASS H.R. 12384, AUTHORIZING FUNDS FOR FISCAL YEAR 1977 FOR CONSTRUCTION  OF CERTAIN MILITARY INSTALLATIONS, AFTER STRIKING ALL AFTER THE ENACTING CLAUSE AND INSERTING THE PROVISIONS OF THE SENATE COMPANION BILL, S. 3434.
TO AMEND THE CULVER AMENDMENT, IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE, TO H.R. 12438, BY  BARRING THE USE OF ANY FUNDING FOR PURPOSES OF PROCUREMENT IN CONNECTION WITH THE B-1 BOMBER PROGRAM.  (SEE RC 185)
TO AMEND H.R. 12438, BY BARRING FUNDS TO BE OBLIGATED FOR THE B-1 BOMBER  PROGRAM PRIOR TO FEBRUARY 1, 1977.
TO AMEND H.R. 12438, BY RESTORING HOUSE-PASSED LANGUAGE SETTING RESERVE  MANPOWER CEILING AT 102,000.

TO AMEND H.R. 12455, AUTHORIZING FUNDS TO EXTEND CHILD CARE AND SOCIAL  SERVICES PROGRAMS, BY DELETING THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT PROVIDING $375 MILLION IN ADDITIONAL CHILD CARE FUNDING THROUGH SEPT. 30, 1977 AND PROVIDING FOR THE EMPLOYMENT OF WELFARE RECEIPIENTS IN CHILD CARE JOBS.

TO PASS H.R. 12455, AUTHORIZING FUNDS TO EXTEND CHILD CARE AND SOCIAL SERVICES  PROGRAMS, AFTER AGREEING TO A COMMITTEE AMENDMENT IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE, WHICH WOULD LET STATES DETERMINE SPECIFIC ELIGIBILITY STANDARDS FOR PROGRAMS DIRECTED TOWARD LOWER INCOME FAMILIES.
TO ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF WILLIAM L. SPRINGER TO BE A  MEMBER OF THE FEDERAL ELECTION COMMISSION.
Issue1: Campaign Contributions, Lobbying/House Ethics Campaign Laws

description: TO ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF S. JOHN BYINGTON TO BE A COMMISSIONER OF THE CONSUMER PRODUCT SAFETY COMMISSION.
TO AMEND H.R. 12438, BY DELETING $120 MILLION IN FUNDING FOR PROCUREMENT OF  ADDITIONAL 24 A7-D TYPE AIRCRAFT FOR THE AIR NATIONAL GUARD.
TO TABLE A MOTION TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE BY WHICH THE NOMINATION OF S. JOHN  BYINGTON TO THE CONSUMER PRODUCT SAFETY COMMISSION WAS REJECTED.
TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE BY WHICH THE NOMINATION OF S. JOHN BYINGTON TO THE  CONSUMER PRODUCT SAFETY COMMISSION WAS REJECTED.
TO AGREE TO A MODIFIED AMENDMENT TO H.R. 12438.  THE KENNEDY AMENDMENT DELETES  317 MILLION FOR PROCUREMENT OF 60 ADDITIONAL MINUTEMAN III MISSLES.
TO AMEND H.R. 12438, BY INCREASING FROM 190,000 TO 196,000 THE CEILING ON  ACTIVE DUTY MARINE CORPS PERSONNEL.
TO ADVISE AND CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF S. JOHN BYINGTON TO BE A  COMMISSIONER OF THE CONSUMER PRODUCT SAFETY COMMISSION.  (ON RECONSIDERATION)

TO TABLE THE TOWER APPEAL FROM THE RULING OF THE CHAIR THAT A POINT OF ORDER BE  SUSTAINED, ON GROUNDS OF GERMANESS AGAINST THE TOWER AMENDMENT TO H.R. 12438 AUTHORIZING $100 MILLION FOR AIR FORCE PROCUREMENT OF 20 A7-D TYPE AIRCRAFT FOR USE BY THE NATIONAL GUARD.
TO AMEND H.R. 12438, BY INCREASING FROM 79,500 TO 92,000 THE CEILING ON NAVAL  RESERVE MANPOWER.

TO TABLE THE TAFT AMENDMENT TO H.R. 12438.  THE TAFT AMENDMENT AUTHORIZES THE  PRESIDENT TO USE FUNDS TO PROCURE B-1 BOMBER AIRCRAFT PRIOR TO FEB. 1, 1977, IF HE DETERMINES THAT PRODUCTION OF SUCH AIRCRAFT WILL IMPROVE CHANCES FOR SUCCESSFUL SALT NEGOTIATIONS.
TO PASS H.R. 12438.

TO DISCHARGE THE COMMITTEE ON INTERIOR AND INSULAR AFFAIRS FROM FURTHER  CONSIDERATION OF S. RES. 449, TO EXPRESS DISAPPROVAL OF ENERGY ACTION NO. 2, A PROPOSAL TO MODIFY THE PRESENT CRUDE OIL ENTITLEMENT PURCHASE EXEMPTION FOR SMALL REFINERS.

TO TABLE THE ALLEN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 8532, A BILL TO AMEND THE CLAYTON ACT  TO PERMIT STATE ATTORNEYS GENERAL TO BRING CERTAIN ANTITRUST ACTIONS.  THE ALLEN AMENDMENT, IN THE NATURE OF A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE HART SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT, EMBODIES THE TEXT OF THE HOUSE BILL WITH THE ADDED PROVISO THAT THE ACT NOT BE APPLICABLE IN A STATE UNTIL THAT STATE PROVIDES BY LAW FOR ITS APPLICABILITY.

TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT TO THE HART SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 8532.  THE MORGAN AMENDMENT LIMITS TITLE IV TO SPECIFIC OFFENSES AND FRAUD ON THE PATENT OFFICE AND APPLYING PROVISIONS PROSPECTIVELY ONLY.  THE HART SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT AUTHORIZES STATE ATTORNEYS-GENERAL TO BRING ANTITRUST SUITS ON BEHALF OF CITIZENS, REQUIRES COMPANIES TO NOTIFY THE GOVERNMENT OF PLANNED MERGERS, AND STRENGTHENS GOVERNMENTS ANTI-TRUST INVESTIGATIVE POWERS.
TO TABLE THE MORGAN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 8532.  THE MORGAN SUBSTITUTE FOR THE  ALLEN SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT EMBODIES PROVISIONS OF THE HART AMENDMENT, AS AMENDED. (SEE RC 202, 203 .

TO TABLE THE MONDALE UNPRINTED SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT FOR COMMITTEE AMENDMENT #13  TO H.R. 10612.  THE MONDALE AMENDMENT INCREASES THE MINIMUM RATE TO 15% FROM 10%, PROVIDES AN EXEMPTION OF $10,000 FROM PREFERENCE INCOME SUBJECT TO THE TAX WITH NO DEDUCTION FOR REGULAR TAXES PAID, AND EXPANDS THE LIST OF PREFERENCE ITEMS, APPLYING ALL CHANGES TO CORPORATIONS AS WELL AS INDIVIDUALS.  THE FINANCE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT INCREASES TO 15% THE MINIMUM RATE TAXES, PROVIDES AN EXEMPTION OF $5,000 OR PAID TAXES, WHICHEVER IS HIGHER, INCREASES THE TYPES OF PREFERENCE INCOME AND APPLIES THE CHANGES TO INDIVIDUALS ONLY.
TO TABLE THE ALLEN AMENDMENT TO THE MONDALE SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT. THE ALLEN  AMENDMENT EXEMPTS THE HIGHER OF EITHER $10,000 OR REGULAR TAXES PAID FROM PREFERENCE INCOME TAX SUBJECT TO MINIMUM TAX.
TO TABLE THE MONDALE SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT FOR THE ALLEN AMENDMENT (SEE  R.C. 333) TO H.R. 10612.  THE MONDALE SUBSTITUTE APPLIES CHANGES IN THE MINIMUM TAX ONLY TO INDIVIDUALS.

TO AMEND THE HOUSE-PASSED LANGUAGE OF H.R. 10612, BY APPLYING MINIMUM TAX  CHANGES TO CORPORATIONS AND EXEMPTING FROM PREFERENCE ALL INCOME SUBJECT TO THE MINIMUM TAX THE HIGHER OF $10,000 OR THE REGULAR TAXES PAID.

TO AGREE TO A SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT FOR THE MONDALE REVISED SUBSTITUTE  AMENDMENT (SEE R.C. 336) FOR THE FINANCE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 10612. THE BROCK SUBSTITUTE PROPOSES THAT MINIMUM TAXES BE PAID ACCORDING TO THE HIGHEST ESTIMATE COMPUTED BY EITHER A FLAT RATE OR A REGULAR TAX METHOD.
TO AMEND THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT #13 (SEE R.C. 330) TO H.R. 10612, BY  EXEMPTING CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS FROM THE MINIMUM TAX.

TO TABLE THE REVISED MONDALE SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT FOR THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  #13 (SEE R.C. 330) TO H.R. 10612.  THE MONDALE SUBSTITUTE INCREASES THE MINIMUM TAX RATE FROM 10% TO 15%, INCREASES THE TYPES OF PREFERENCE INCOME AND APPLIES THE CHANGE ONLY TO INDIVIDUALS.
TO TABLE THE MOTION TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE BY WHICH THE SENATE AGREED TO  TABLE THE MONDALE REVISED SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT (SEE R.C. 336) FOR THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT #13 TO H.R. 10612.

TO TABLE THE BUMPERS SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT FOR THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT #13  TO H.R 10612.  THE BUMPERS AMENDMENT INCREASES THE MINIMUM TAX RATE TO 152, EXEMPTS FROM PREFERENCE INCOME EITHER $10,000 OR HALF OF PAID TAXES, WHICHEVER IS LARGER, AND EXCLUDES THE TIMBER INDUSTRY FROM MINIMUM TAX CHANGES AND FROM CAPITAL GAINS TAX FROM SALE OF INDIVIDUAL HOMES.
TO TABLE THE KENNEDY MOTION TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE BY WHICH THE SENATE REJECTED THE BUMPERS SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT (SEE R.C. 338) FOR THE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT #13 TO H.R. 10612.  (SEE R.C. 330)

TO AGREE TO A SUBSTITUTE AMENDMENT FOR THE FINANCE COMMITTEE AMENDMENT #13 (SEE  R.C. 330) TO H.R. 10612.  THE ALLEN AMENDMENT INCREASES THE MINIMUM TAX RATE TO 15%, EXCLUDES FROM PREFERENCE INCOME $10,000 OR PAID TAXES, WHICHEVER IS GREATER, INCREASES THE TYPES OF PREFERENCE INCOME, AND APPLIES THE CHANGES TO INDIVIDUALS AND CORPORATIONS, WITH EXCEPTION OF THE TIMBER INDUSTRY.
